title: Cardiopteridaceae
text:
Cardiopteridaceae is a <a href="eudicot">eudicot</a> <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s. It consists of about 43 <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="tree">tree</a>s, <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s, and <a href="Woody%20plant">woody</a> <a href="vine">vine</a>s, mostly of the <a href="tropics">tropics</a>, but with a few in <a href="Temperateness">temperate</a> regions. It contains six <a href="genera">genera</a>, the largest of which is "<a href="Citronella%20%28genus%29">Citronella</a>", with 21 species. The other genera are much smaller.
"<a href="Citronella%20mucronata">Citronella mucronata</a>" is grown as an <a href="Ornamental%20plant">ornamental</a> for its attractively shiny leaves and fragrant flowers. A <a href="tea">tea</a> is made from the leaves of "<a href="Citronella%20gongonha">Citronella gongonha</a>" which is similar to <a href="yerba%20mat%C3%A9">yerba maté</a>.
The <a href="APG%20II%20system">APG III classification (2009)</a> places them in the order <a href="Aquifoliales">Aquifoliales</a>. This order consists of Cardiopteridaceae, its <a href="Cladistics%23Subtrees%20are%20clades">sister</a> family, <a href="Stemonuraceae">Stemonuraceae</a>, and the three <a href="monogeneric">monogeneric</a> families <a href="Phyllonomaceae">Phyllonomaceae</a>, <a href="Helwingiaceae">Helwingiaceae</a>, and <a href="Aquifoliaceae">Aquifoliaceae</a>.
The family name.
The family Cardiopteridaceae was established by <a href="Carl%20Ludwig%20Blume">Carl Ludwig Blume</a> in 1847 when he described the species "Cardiopteris moluccana". Blume based his new family on "Cardiopteris", a <a href="Botanical%20name">name</a> that had previously been used by <a href="John%20Forbes%20Royle">John Royle</a> and <a href="Nathaniel%20Wallich">Nathaniel Wallich</a>, but not <a href="Valid%20name%20%28botany%29">validly published</a>. In 1843, <a href="Justus%20Hasskarl">Justus Hasskarl</a> had published the name "Peripterygium quinqueloba" for what is now "Cardiopteris quinqueloba". Blume indicated his awareness of Hasskarl's plant and included it as another species of "Cardiopteris" when he published "Cardiopteris moluccana".
A complex <a href="Plant%20taxonomy">nomenclatural</a> dispute ensued and lasted well into the twentieth century. Because the <a href="basionym">basionym</a>, "Cardiopteris", was in question, the corresponding family name Cardiopteridaceae was in question as well. The <a href="ICBN">ICBN</a> finally <a href="Conserved%20name">conserved</a> the name "Cardiopteris" against "Peripterygium".
Circumscription.
Prior to the seminal study by Kårehed in 2001, Cardiopteridaceae had consisted of only "Cardiopteris". For example, <a href="Hermann%20Otto%20Sleumer">Hermann Sleumer</a> considered it to be monogeneric in his <a href="Treatise">treatment</a> of the family for <a href="Die%20Nat%C3%BCrlichen%20Pflanzenfamilien">Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien</a> in 1942. <a href="John%20Hutchinson%20%28botanist%29">John Hutchinson</a> did likewise in 1973.
In 2001, Icacinaceae was shown to be <a href="polyphyletic">polyphyletic</a>. It has since been divided into five <a href="Segregate%20%28taxonomy%29">segregate</a> families: Cardiopteridaceae, <a href="Stemonuraceae">Stemonuraceae</a>, <a href="Pennantiaceae">Pennantiaceae</a>, <a href="Metteniusaceae">Metteniusaceae</a>, and <a href="Icacinaceae">Icacinaceae</a> <a href="sensu%20stricto">sensu stricto</a>. Icacinaceae sensu stricto will eventually be divided further.
In the 2001 study of Icacinaceae, Kårehed transferred "Citronella, Gonocaryum," and "Leptaulus" from Icacinaceae to Cardiopteridaceae. He also provisionally placed "Metteniusa, Dendrobangia," and "Pseudobotrys" there as well, until further studies could give some firm indication of their true relationships.
In 2007, a <a href="molecular%20phylogenetic">molecular phylogenetic</a> study showed that "Metteniusa" belongs to a group of <a href="asterids">asterids</a> known as the <a href="lamiids">lamiids</a>. The order Aquifoliales, which includes Cardiopteridaceae, belongs to another asterid group called <a href="campanulids">campanulids</a>.
The inclusion of "<a href="Pseudobotrys">Pseudobotrys</a>" in Cardiopteridaceae remains doubtful. DNA sequences submitted to GenBank in 2009 indicate that "<a href="Dendrobangia">Dendrobangia</a>" does not belong in Cardiopteridaceae and is more closely related to genera like Apodytes.
Cardiopteridaceae, <a href="sensu">sensu</a> Kårehed, is rather <a href="Biodiversity">diverse</a> in spite of having only six genera. Because of the distinctive <a href="Plant%20morphology">structure</a> of "Cardiopteris", some authors today, continue to put "Cardiopteris" in a family by itself. The other five genera are then placed in Leptaulaceae, a family created by <a href="Philippe%20%C3%89douard%20L%C3%A9on%20Van%20Tieghem">Philippe van Tieghem</a> in 1897. The <a href="monophyly">monophyly</a> of Leptaulaceae has never been tested by <a href="phylogenetic">phylogenetic</a> analysis of <a href="DNA%20sequence">DNA sequence</a>s.
